fields.headline: Liz Green: O, Devotion! – review
fields.bodyText: "I want to be a French singer," trills Liz Green. "I'd sing for you, my lover, all night/ Then maybe we'd learn to float above it all." Those few words encapsulate all she's trying to achieve on her debut album: placing herself outside the earnest, folksy singer-songwriter trope into which so many young female singers are being shoehorned at the moment, and away from the vagaries of fashion, turning instead to a music that's a little bit chanson, a little bit blues, a little bit jazz, a little bit cabaret. She's got an ear for memorable phrasing – "Hang him out to dry, they said/ No, let's hang him up to die instead," is the opening couplet of Ostrich Song – and a smoky, slightly nasal voice. But she never quite lets her music become as exuberant as it needs to be – for all that her voice and guitar are backed by trombone, tuba, tenor sax, trumpet, double bass and even kazoo, it's muted and sometimes solemn, without the breathtaking pizzazz Anaïs Mitchell brought to similar styles on her Hadestown album. Still, it's a debut, and suggests a talent that will only grow.
